â
The '''Egyptian presidential election, 2011''' is the second allegedly contested presidential election in [[Egypt]]'s history. [[Hosni Mubarak]], the [[incumbent]] [[Rulers and heads of state of Egypt|President of Egypt]], may not run for this election which opens the door for many names to be suggested to take his place as President of Egypt. Some of those names are [[Ahmed Zewail]] ''([[Egyptians|Egyptian]]-American scientist, and the winner of the 1999 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] for his work on [[femtochemistry]])'', [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] ''(the ex-Director General of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA), and the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 2005)'', [[Amr Moussa]] ''(the current [[Secretary-General]] of the [[League of Arab States]], and He is a former [[Egypt]]ian [[Foreign Minister]])'', [[Mamdouh Ramzi]] ''([[Coptic]] [[Lawyer]])'', and [[Gamal Mubarak]] ''(the younger of the two sons of current [[Egypt]]ian President [[Hosni Mubarak]])'' among others.
+
The '''Egyptian presidential election, 2011''' is the second allegedly contested presidential election in [[Egypt]]'s history. [[Hosni Mubarak]], the [[incumbent]] [[Rulers and heads of state of Egypt|President of Egypt]], may not run for this election which opens the door for many names to be suggested to take his place as President of Egypt. Some of those names are [[Ahmed Zewail]] ''([[Egyptians|Egyptian]]-American scientist, and the winner of the 1999 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] for his work on [[femtochemistry]])'', [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] ''(the ex-Director General of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA), and the winner of the 2005 [[Nobel Peace Prize]])'', [[Amr Moussa]] ''(the current [[Secretary-General]] of the [[League of Arab States]], and He is a former [[Egypt]]ian [[Foreign Minister]])'', [[Mamdouh Ramzi]] ''([[Coptic]] [[Lawyer]])'', and [[Gamal Mubarak]] ''(the younger of the two sons of current [[Egypt]]ian President [[Hosni Mubarak]])'' among others.
==Proposals==
==Proposals==
Line 19: Line 19:
He added: Â«If there any hope that next line of presidents of Egypt will not belong to the "Solid Foundation" -- Represented in the military or intelligence or from The Egyptian Federal Bureau of InvestigationâIt has to happen in the presence of President MubarakÂ». He also said Â«If fate decided that institutions of the State to choose a President in the absence of President Mubarak -- for any of the constitutional reasons set forth on the absence of the President -- It is certain in my mind that the next President of Egypt will be from the "Solid Foundation"Â».
He added: Â«If there any hope that next line of presidents of Egypt will not belong to the "Solid Foundation" -- Represented in the military or intelligence or from The Egyptian Federal Bureau of InvestigationâIt has to happen in the presence of President MubarakÂ». He also said Â«If fate decided that institutions of the State to choose a President in the absence of President Mubarak -- for any of the constitutional reasons set forth on the absence of the President -- It is certain in my mind that the next President of Egypt will be from the "Solid Foundation"Â».
  +   +
He also said in another interview to [[Al-Shorouk (Egyptian newspaper)|Al-Shorouk]] that the citizens and the people are with President Mubarak but not with ''the president's party'' by showing that Mubarak won the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2005|the last presidential election]] by more than the proportion that achieved the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] in [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2005|the last parliamentary election]].
  +   +
== Potential candidates ==
  +
=== Mohamed Hosni Mubarak ===
  +   +
Mohamed Hosni Mubarak is the main candidate and the number one candidate for [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|the NDP]] in the next presidential election. He will run unless he felt that he is too old (He will be 83 in the [[2011]]) or that his parental instinct overpowers his love of power and decides its time to leave his inheritance to his son, Gamal Mubarak.
  +   +
=== Omar Suleiman ===
  +
[[Omar Suleiman]] is the head of [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] and plays an important role in [[FatahâHamas conflict|mediation between Palestinian factions]] as well as coordination between [[IsraeliâPalestinian conflict|the Palestinian and the Israelis]].
  +   +
Many in Egypt believe that the security services (i.e. Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate) and state security are governing the state effectively and guide the presidential decisions.
  +   +
His name has been Been put forward as a candidate for the presidency by some writers and intellectuals as an alternative to the idea of bequeathing power to Gamal Mubarak.
  +   +
=== Gamal Mubarak ===
  +   +
Gamal Mubarak did not specify the position so far from the elections, in 2011, leaving the door open to the rumors.
  +   +
On the other hand, a number of forces, and national popular movements and opposition political parties in [[Egypt]] is sharply critical of the regime, accusing him of seeking "to pass Gamal Mubarak, President of the Republic" to replace his father, and many of those parties and opposition parties opposed to what it describes as "the inheritance scheme ".
  +   +
The afternoon is another one of the elite of Egyptian youth to defend Gamal Mubarak and his right to his chair in Egypt.
  +   +
=== Mohamed ElBaradei ===
  +   +
In [[November]] [[2009]] and in the midst of political controversy over the election of the presidency of the '''Republic of Egypt''' in [[2011]] and constitutional impediments placed in front of candidates under the amended Article 76 in constitution 2007 and speculation about the escalation of President Hosni Mubarak's son, Mohamed ElBaradei stated the he might run for the presidential elections in Egypt. The condition of his declaration is a "written assurances" about the integrity and freedom of the electoral process from the Egyptian Government. ElBaradei said in a television interview he conducted with [[CNN News]]: "I will study the possibility of running for presidential candidate in Egypt if there any written guarantees that the electoral process will be free and fair."
  +   +
Declaration ElBaradei has elicited mixed reactions in the Egyptian political world. Where some consider an embarrassing message to the regime from a "heavy weight" international figure to push the regime to solve review the process of devolution of power in Egypt. While others felt that the UN nuclear watchdog is a real effort to open new horizons for political life "strangulated" in Egypt.
  +   +
ElBaradei said in a statement sent from his office in Vienna to [[Al-Shorouk (Egyptian newspaper)|Al-Shorouk]] '''"He did not announce willingness or unwillingness to participate in the upcoming presidential election... and that he will clear his position on the presidency after November"'''<ref name="ElBaradei will clear his position on the presidency after November">[http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=136398 ElBaradei will clear his position on the presidency after November]</ref>. His office manager added: {{Quotation|Dr. ElBaradei is the Director General of [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) until the end of November. Therefore, He is currently devoted to his work and to address the important issues and topics that needs to be addressed by the Agency. So he did not take any decision regarding his future which will be decided in light of developments of the next phase.}}
  +   +
The [[New Wafd Party|Al-Wafd Party]] and other opposition political forces has announced that they are ready to support ElBaradei if he decided to run. But Mohamed ElBaradei said that if he decides to run in the presidential election in Egypt in 2011, He will run as an independent candidate instead of running as a candidate of any of the [[List of political parties in Egypt|political parties in Egypt]]<ref name="ElBaradei exclude running in the presidential elections in Egypt as a candidate of the any political party">[http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE5B90J120091210 ElBaradei exclude running in the presidential elections in Egypt as a candidate of the any political party]</ref>.
  +   +
=== Ahmed Zewail ===
  +   +
When asked about the rumors that He might run for Egyptian presidential election in 2011 and his political ambitions, Ahmed Zewail Said: "I am a frank man .. I have no political ambition, as I have stressed repeatedly that I only want to serve Egypt in the field of science and die as a scientist."<ref name="Zewail: I have no political ambitions .. I would like service of Egypt a scientist only">[http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=133290 Zewail: I have no political ambitions .. I would like service of Egypt a scientist only]</ref>
  +   +
=== Amr Moussa ===
  +   +
When asked about the rumors that He might run for Egyptian presidential election in 2011, Amr Moussa he did not deny his intention to run for office or ruled it out, leaving the door open to expectations. He argued that "It's the right of every citizen that has the capacity and efficiency to aspire to any political office that would allow him to contribute to the service of his nation"<ref name="Amr Moussa opened the way for speculation about his candidacy for the presidency of Egypt">[http://arabic.cnn.com/2009/middle_east/10/20/Amro.Mousa/ Amr Moussa opened the way for speculation about his candidacy for the presidency of Egypt]</ref>. He further stated to the press that the qualities required to be the President of [[Egypt|The Republic of Egpyt]] also apply to [[Gamal Mubarak]], son of the [[Egypt]]ian President [[Hosni Mubarak]], say that citizenship, rights and obligations apply to him can be also apply to [[Gamal Mubarak]]<ref name="Amr Moussa did not rule out running for the presidency of Egypt">[http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE59I1E020091020 Amr Moussa did not rule out running for the presidency of Egypt]</ref>. He also expressed appreciation "for the confidence expressed by many people when they talk about his candidacy for the presidency and that the message reached him."<ref name="Amr Mousa to (Al-Shorouk): Every qualified citizen has the right to aspire to serve the country and become the president">[http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=143426 Amr Mousa to (Al-Shorouk): Every qualified citizen has the right to aspire to serve the country and become the president]</ref>.
  +   +
=== Sameh Ashour ===
  +   +
=== Ayman Nour ===
  +
[[Ayman Nour]]is the founder and leader of [[Al-Ghad Party]] and former candidate in the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2005|2005 presidential elections]] were he lost and became runner-up to President Mubarak.
  +   +
Ayman Nour was jailed in [[2006]] after the presidential election by few months on charges of [[forgery]]. Later he was excluded from the party presidency. In [[February]] [[2009]], he was released from prison under an amnesty due health reason. The press leaked that Ayman Nour was released from prison due to Obama demanding this release as a condition to meeting with Mubarak {{fact|December 2009}}.
  +   +
Ayman Nour may not be able to run for president in 2011 because of charges and imprisonment.
  +   +
=== Rifaat El-Said ===
  +   +
=== Mahmoud Abaza ===
  +   +
=== Mamdouh Ramzi ===
  +   +
== Criticisms of the 2011 Presidential Election Arrangements ==
  +
=== Election monitoring ===
  +   +
This election will not be under any court supervision and international supervision of these elections as was rejected. The General Secretary of the Policy Committee in the [[National Democratic Party]] '''Gamal Mubarak''' said, in a press conference '''"This issue is governed by the law and the constitution which made it possible for civil society organizations to monitor the elections"'''. The Secretary of Education in the party, [[Mohamed Kamal]], said that the party welcomes the supervision of national organizations, but he refuses to international monitoring. He then add that the abolition of judicial supervision of elections does not affect its integrity. {{Quotation|'''"Most of the world has no judicial supervision of elections, however, those elections are fair and impartial."'''<ref name="Â«National Democratic PartyÂ» emphasizes the unity of the parliamentary majority to reap ... And rejects any international monitoring of elections">[http://international.daralhayat.com/internationalarticle/72415 Â«National Democratic PartyÂ» emphasizes the unity of the parliamentary majority to reap ... And rejects any international monitoring of elections]</ref>}}
